title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
Intel ousted CEO Swan after a period of technology missteps, market-share losses and pressure from hedge fund Third Point. The chip giant said he would be succeeded by VMware chief Gelsinger.

---

The U.S. is expected to let Americans continue to invest in Alibaba, Tencent and Baidu after weighing the firms' alleged ties to China's military against the potential economic impact of banning them.

---

Canada's Couche-Tard, a big operator of convenience stores, said it made a $19.66 billion offer for French hypermarket chain Carrefour.

---

Citigroup is restructuring its businesses that manage money for the wealthy, as incoming CEO Fraser moves to put her stamp on the bank.

---

BlackRock's Novick will transition from her role as vice chairman to become a senior adviser, taking a second stab at retirement.

---

The S&P 500 and Nasdaq posted gains of 0.2% and 0.4%, respectively, while the Dow fell 8.22 points, or less than 0.1%.

---

Federal regulators asked Tesla to recall about 158,000 vehicles over safety concerns tied to the failure of touch screens.

---

Connecticut is actively investigating how Amazon sells and distributes digital books, according to the state's attorney general.

---

Europe's antitrust watchdog approved the LSE's $15 billion deal to acquire financial-data company Refinitiv, with conditions.
